content.description: Follow the nice hand crack up to the roof, then traverse right out from under the roof, and face climb up. Large tree for an anchor. Rap from the tree, or walk off.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts. The initial crack takes large hexes and #3-4 BD cams.
content.location: From the Whitewater Creek Trailhead, follow the river for roughly 0.7 miles to the fork between E Palisades Trail and Whitewater Creek Trail. Take the left and follow E Palisades Trail for roughly 1000 ft across a thin trail on the bank of the river. The path splits again but the crack should be visible from the fork. It is just up a short ways on the trail leading to the right. The route is the first significant sized wall, at the obvious hand crack. Roughly at 33°53'18.0"N 84°26'32.4"W. Alternatively, whitewater Crack could be accessed via the Akers Mill Trail Access Point boat ramp. Kayak directly across the Chattahoochee to the E Palisades Trail at the base of the climb.

content.description: Climb up face on cool crimps and pockets. Easy to top protect with trees and cams. A sketchy lead.
content.location: Just down river of ep 16. First cliff of the left.

content.description: Scramble up mossy base and climb up and right of the prow on good cracks and crimps. Gear is easy at the top and bottom but thin in the middle. Takes most nuts and cams smaller than 1. Tat at the top for a rappel, or scramble down right side
content.location: Second cliff on left after walking downriver from ep. 16.

climbs.name: Simba
climbs.fa: Justin J., Samuel S., Amber S., Carter Rechsteiner

content.description:
"All that the light touches is on" 

 Fun slab problem. Climb up the mix of crimps, slopers, and jugs to a dirty top out. Many different lines that are all 0-1 grade.
content.location: Go downriver from Ep. 16 for about .5 miles. Climb up zig zag cliffside trail. There is a large landing area looking over the river.

content.description: Start on right crimp and left undercling flake. Move up and right in the cracks to an akward mantle.
content.location: Down river from ledge lesson. Tucked between two cliffs. Just past the large overhung pride rock style cliff.

content.description: Start on flake sidepull on far right and move up on quartz pinches and crimps. Mantle top.
content.location: Same boulder as boat rope. Downriver of ledge lesson, just past large pride rock style rock.

climbs.name: Little Girl, You're In the Middle of the Ride

content.description: Go up the middle block of the Jimmy Eat World Boulder using crimps and side pulls on the aréte. The left and right blocks are off. Slopey top out.
content.protection: Pads and a very good spotter
content.location: Just right of simba. Down river of ep 16 after the trail starts going up into the cliff face.

content.description: Ledges and ledges. Easy climb with lots of opportunity to fall on a ledge (pg13). Ends in a skinny chimney. Tat on tree above
content.protection: Tat at top. A #4 bd can be used at the top. Other small cams and nuts
content.location: Just left of Bring out the crimps. cliff side area. Heading south from ep16 following the river. second prowl -up the hill to the left.

content.description: Worm your way up the body crack to a mantle top. This climb is definitely size dependant on your pants size.
content.location: On Jimmy Eat World Boulder. Downriver of ep 16 right after the trail goes up the cliff face.

content.description: Climb up the crack with jams and crimps. Avoid the tree dab.
content.location: On Jimmy Eat World Boulder. Downriver of ep 16 just after the trail goes up the cliff.

content.description: Crimpy little tower. Stick to the face of the tower as best you can, but use the arete if you must. Plenty of little foot ledges for rest if need be, but it's a fun little route up the little spire, needle thingy.
content.protection: Top rope off tree behind the little needle.
content.location: You can see this formation from the trail by turning down river at marker EP16, and go passed the old stone house foundation about 50-75 yards. There are several formations that I'm still working to find routes on. This route is on the middle formation and right at the top of the little path that breaks off the main trail, identifiable by the little needle.

content.description: Stretch of cliff faces and boulders along the Chattahoochee. There seems to be a potential for hard sport routes if bolted. Otherwise, most cliffs have top access and plenty of trees for anchors.
